awd_titl_txt: Travel Grant: 10th International Conference on Multiscale Materials Modeling; Baltimore, Maryland; October 19-22, 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides travel support for the 10th International Conference on Multiscale Materials Modeling, which will be held at the Johns Hopkins University campus in Baltimore, Maryland, on October 19-22, 2020. The conference will be jointly hosted by George Mason University, Georgetown University, and the University of Maryland. Multiscale materials modeling (MMM) is a branch of computational mechanics, computational biomechanics, and computational materials science in which existing and emerging methods from interdisciplinary fields are combined to bridge phenomena, which are inherent to complex material systems, across different length and time scales. MMM provides direct insights on how materials (or living matter) deform and/or adapt their form and function in response to different mechanical, electrical, magnetic, or environmental exciters, and trace this to material structure and molecular (or cellular) level mechanisms. MMM is also indispensable for expediting the development and manufacturing of reliable materials with superior performance by moving away from empirical trial-and-error techniques, to state-of-the-art and experimentally verified multi-scale computational methods. This grant will help to considerably subsidize travel costs, through scholarships, for 50 graduate students and 25 junior researchers, with emphasis on under-representative groups, to participate, showcase their work, as well as interact with leaders in the MMM community who regularly attend this conference. These travel fellowships will also help promote/highlight NSF-funded research focused on MMM.

This four-day conference brings together researchers from academia, national laboratories, and industry from across the globe with interdisciplinary research backgrounds in mechanics, biomechanics and mechanobiology, materials, advanced manufacturing, and computational mechanics and sciences to share new advancements in the field and identify existing and future challenges. Each day there will be an hour-long plenary session, two 45 minutes semi-plenary sessions, and 5.5 hours of 9 to 13 parallel technical sessions. Each technical session will be composed of multiple 20 minutes contributed presentations and 30 minutes invited presentations. There will also be two separate evening poster sessions in which a student poster competition will be held. The outcome of this conference will be disseminated in the form of several peer reviewed journal special issues that would feature several conference articles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The tenth international conference on multiscale materials modeling (MMM 10) was held October 2-7, 2022 in Baltimore, MD. The MMM conference is the world?s largest conference series focused on different aspects of MMM as pertaining to the fields of mechanics of materials, biomechanics, advanced manufacturing, and computational sciences. One of the main themes of the MMM 10 in Baltimore was "Enabling Materials Prediction, Design, and Manufacturing through rigorous scale bridging and materials informatics".  With the attendance of 647 scientists (~50% of which were students and junior researchers) from 27 countries around the world, MMM 10 was a global forum for researchers from academia, national laboratories, and industrial research facilities worldwide to showcase and discuss the current state-of-the-art in MMM as well as identify new opportunities in the field.

The goal of this NSF grant was to increase the participation of students and junior researchers in the conference, with particular emphasis on increasing the participation of women and other under-represented minorities in science an engineering by providing substantial travel fellowships. This grant, and with additional support from other federal agencies and private funding sources, has enabled supporting a total of 73 travel fellowships (covering registration fees, local accommodation, and in some cases travel expenses) for US based attendees. Of those, 43 were for students, 16 for postdocs, 7 for junior scientists, and 7 for early career tenure track faculty, with a total of 20% of the awardees identifying as women and under-representative minorities. The conference was an ideal forum for students and junior researchers to be exposed to the state-of-the-art in MMM, as well as to showcase their own research as oral talks or poster presentations to world renowned experts and gain instant recognition in the field. Additionally, the funds contributed to the registration fees, local accommodation, and travel of 3 US based women prominent scientists to contribute as plenary and semi-plenary speakers.  A total of 6 best student poster awards and one Early Career Investigator Award were given out during the conference as selected by a panel of world-renowned experts in the field.

 


Last Modified: 04/24/2023
Modified by: Jaafar El-Awady
